My wife wants asked me to get some zero calorie cooking spray at the store. When I saw the can it said it was 100% avocado oil and also zero-calorie. This seemed really suspicious to me since oil is pure calories. So I looked at the back, turns out the way they're able to say that it has zero calories is by claiming that the can contains many tens of thousands of servings. The product contains exactly the same amount of calories as any other pure oil product, but they divided into so many servings that any single serving has fewer calories than what the federal government dictates is necessary to count as containing calories. In other words they're just flatly lying to you. My wife was super pissed

More importantly the calorie content is not significantly better (or better at all) than any regular cereal. Most of these gimmick cereals still have 140+ kcal per serving. Maybe it's slightly better to get those calories from fat and protein instead of refined sugars but in terms of obesity and cholesterol, there's basically no difference at all. So you pay $6 for a box that's almost half the size of most $3-4 cereals and you get a product that basically just shuffles some of the macronutrients around but is otherwise the exact same.

Gotta love misleading packaging. Recently our whole family went on a diet to eat healthier and to lose some.. unwanted weight, and we normally like to eat tacos and tostadas (tortilla based meals) and there's this one company that advertises each tortilla of theirs is 1/3 of a normal one. Well, our nutriologist told us that each normal tortilla has, let's say, 50g. Turns out, if you read the packaging of these "3=1" tortillas, it says that each tortilla is something like 22g, meaning that 2 of these are just barely below one normal tortilla. since there's still 6-ish grams the'yre able to say that 3 equals 1, even though it's actually untrue!
